docs.lead_paragraph: Birth control pills have no significant effect on the risk of developing breast cancer before 45 years of age, according to the largest study of the issue yet conducted. The researchers said their finding held true no matter how old the women were when they started using the pill, how long they used it, whether they started taking the pill before the birth of the first child or how much of the hormone progestogen was contained in the pills. ''We now have a great deal of confidence that pill use does not affect young women's risk of breast cancer,'' said Dr. Bruce V. Stadel of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development. He was the senior scientist in the study of more than 4,000 women 20 to 44 years old in eight regions of the country.

headline.main: U.S. FINDS BREAST CANCER RATE NOT AFFECTED BY TAKING THE PILL

docs.snippet: Birth control pills have no significant effect on the risk of developing breast cancer before 45 years of age, according to the largest study of the issue yet conducted.   The researchers said their finding held true no matter how old the women were...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times
